Title: Apple cider vinegar and weight loss -- what the experts say
Content:
The claims are everywhere: If you add apple cider vinegar to your daily diet, it will help you lose weight. ‚ÄúHelps maintain a healthy weight range,‚Äù declares one manufacturer.


            ‚ÄúA lot of this is marketing,‚Äù said registered dietitian and CNN contributor Lisa Drayer. ‚ÄúConsumers get those messages, and they think, ‚ÄòOh, this must be the next magic bullet.‚Äô But whether it‚Äôs based on science is another matter.‚Äù
    

            A lot of the research on vinegar‚Äôs relationship with weight loss is in animals, mainly mice and rats. Studies show that acetic acid, the main component of apple cider vinegar, can suppress body fat accumulation and metabolic disorders in obese rats. But of course, mice are not men, and rats are not women, so these findings prove little.
    

            Studies in humans have been small, which limits their validity.
    

Related article
5 benefits of apple cider vinegar (and a few duds), according to experts


            ‚ÄúFor example, some research suggests that it might promote satiety and make you consume fewer calories throughout the day,‚Äù Drayer said. ‚ÄúBut the research is very limited, with small sample sizes, and is far from conclusive.‚Äù
    

            A 2005 study of 12 people found participantsfelt fuller when vinegar was consumed witha meal that included bread.A 2013 study of 16 people found the sameresult, but only because the vinegar caused nausea when ingested. ‚ÄúOn this basis, the promotion of vinegar as a natural appetite suppressant does not seem appropriate,‚Äù that study concluded.
    

            The most-cited study to explore a connection to weight loss was done in 2009 with 175 ‚Äúobese‚Äù Japanese subjects, ages 25 to 60, who were split into three groups. Considered ‚Äúobese‚Äù by Japanese standards, each subject‚Äôs body mass index (BMI) was between 25 and 30; in the United States, people aren‚Äôt considered obese until their BMI exceeds 30. Anyone who had high cholesterol or diabetes or was using medications was excluded from the study.
    

            Over a 12-week period, the groups consumed a beverage each day with either one tablespoon of vinegar, two tablespoons of vinegar or no vinegar at all. At the end of the three months, those who consumed any amount of vinegar had a lower body weight, a smaller body mass index, less visceral fat, a smaller waist measurement and lower triglyceride levels than the placebo group that drank no vinegar. 
    

            That sounds fantastic until you look closely at the amount of weight that was lost.
    

            ‚ÄúOnly 2 to 4 pounds in three months over a placebo,‚Äù Drayer explained. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs only a third of a pound a week. Most diets have a much bigger result. So you would definitely have to do many other things to accomplish any significant weight loss.‚Äù
    

            Registered dietitian Carol Johnston has been studying the effects of acetic acid on diabetic blood glucose levels since 2004. While she believes the Japanese study‚Äôs findings make sense because they are in line with animal research, she too is quick to point out that the weight loss in humans was ‚Äúvery, very modest.‚Äù
    

            ‚ÄúIn fact, I would say most people who are on a diet for 12 weeks and only lose a couple of pounds aren‚Äôt going to be very happy,‚Äù said Johnston, an associate dean in the College of Health Solutions at Arizona State University. 
    

            Some claims revolve around using vinegar supplements to lose weight. 
    

            ‚ÄúI remember, probably 15 years ago, covering the apple cider vinegar diet,‚Äù Drayer said. ‚ÄúWhen you looked closely, the diet paired apple cider vinegar pills with a low-calorie menu. It‚Äôs no wonder people lost weight.‚Äù
    

Related article
Stress eating lately? The 'hunger meter' can help


            Many people prefer to ingest vinegar via a pill because liquid vinegar is acidic and can cause nausea. But commercial vinegar pills do not have the same effect on lowering blood glucose as liquid vinegar, according to research done by Johnston.


            If you choose to add vinegar to your diet, Johnston recommends that the tablespoon of vinegar is added to a full glass of water. Properly diluting vinegar is key. Otherwise, it can damage your teeth, throat and stomach lining.
    

            ‚ÄúVinegar has that strong smell and puckering taste, so if you take a breath, you could inhale it into your lungs and burn those a little, because it‚Äôs an acid,‚Äù Johnston said.
    

            Where Johnston‚Äôs research has shown significant benefits from vinegar, however, is in blood sugar control. Over the years, she‚Äôs done a number of studies that show vinegar helps control blood sugar spikes for people with Type 2 diabetes and those who are prediabetic, also known as insulin-resistant. She‚Äôs even seen a slight benefit for healthy control subjects.
    

            ‚ÄúVinegar had an impact in all groups, but the most significant impact was in the prediabetic group,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIn prediabetics, it was too good to be true; (blood sugar) fell a good bit and stayed that way. It may be this is the group that could benefit the most.‚Äù
    

Related article
Should you take a dietary supplement to prevent disease?  


            The theory, according to Johnston, is that acetic acidappears to interfere with enzymes that break down starch molecules. This antiglycemic response can be induced by any sort of vinegar, such as red and white wine vinegars, pomegranate vinegar or even white distilled vinegar. It‚Äôs the acetic acid in the vinegar, not the type, that produces the result. 
    

            ‚ÄúBasically, what acetic acid is doing is blocking the absorption of starch,‚Äù Johnston said. ‚ÄúIf my study subjects eat a starch and add vinegar, glucose will go down. But if they drink sugar water and add vinegar, nothing happens. So if you‚Äôre having bacon and eggs, don‚Äôt bother. It only helps if you are consuming a starch.‚Äù
    

            It‚Äôs possible that blocking starch absorption may help with weight loss as well, Drayer said.
    

            ‚ÄúSo if acetic acid is interfering with the breakdown of starch, what that means is that starch is not being digested,‚Äù she explained. ‚ÄúAnd if it‚Äôs not being digested, it‚Äôs not being absorbed into the bloodstream, and therefore it‚Äôs not contributing to calories.‚Äù
    

Related article
What makes soda so addictive?


            Though the research on acetic acid‚Äôs benefits looks promising, nothing‚Äôs definitive. It could be that other elements in apple cider and other vinegars also play a role. Take the trace chemicals in vinegar that vary based on where each brand was fermented, for example. 
    

            ‚ÄúIt could be that some of those ingredients are important or part of the effect we are seeing,‚Äù Johnson said. She added that it will take much larger randomized scientific trials to prove any cause and effect between vinegar and weight loss, and especially between vinegar and diabetes or cardiovascular risks.
    

            ‚ÄúSomebody, probably the federal government, is going to have to fund a multimillion-dollar grant and recruit hundreds of people at risk for diabetes and metabolic disorders to truly determine if vinegar is going to make a difference,‚Äù Johnston said. 
    

            But until those occur, Johnston sees no harm in using vinegar to control blood sugars after starchy meals. After all, balsamic and wine vinegars are part of the Mediterranean diet, long associated with heart health and other benefits. 
    

Related article
Mediterranean diet named the best for 2019


            ‚ÄúEven in healthy people, that post-meal surge in blood sugar is a risk factor for heart disease, so in my mind, everyone should take advantage of the benefit that vinegar may provide. But I‚Äôd do it the way people have done for centuries, by adding it to their food,‚Äù Johnston said.
    

            ‚ÄúWhat I would recommend is adding vinegar to meals as a condiment, as it contains no calories,‚Äù Drayer said. ‚ÄúWhen you make a dressing, use three parts oil to one part vinegar. Or reverse it and do one part oil and three parts vinegar.‚Äù
    

            You can also use it with food preparation, Drayer added.
    

            ‚ÄúDip your chicken with egg whites and bread crumbs mixed with balsamic vinegar for poultry or fish,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúOr you can drink it in water, which may help as water makes you feel full.‚Äù
    

Sign up here to get The Results Are In with Dr. Sanjay Gupta every Tuesday from the CNN Health team.
    

            But again, never drink vinegar straight, experts say, or you might injure your teeth, throat or stomach.
    

            ‚ÄúDilute it in water, and drink before you eat or with the first bites of your meal,‚Äù Johnston said. ‚ÄúYou want the acetic acid in stomach before the meal to do the most good,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMediterranean people ate the salad with vinegar, then they ate the pasta.‚Äù

            ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a Mac‚Äù actor Justin Long is now a PC guy. 
    

            Nearly two decades ago, Long extolled the benefits of Mac computers while playing one opposite John Hodgman‚Äôs PC in Apple
            
                (AAPL)‚Äôs iconic ‚ÄúGet a Mac‚Äù commercials. Now, in a pointedjab at Apple
            
                (AAPL), Long is featured in a new Intel
            
                (INTC) ad where he appears much more excited about new Intel
            
                (INTC)-based PCs than the latest Mac laptops. 
    

            ‚ÄúHello, I‚Äôm a ‚Äî Justin. Just a real person, doing a real comparison between Mac and PC,‚Äù Long says in the new Intel commercial, an obvious play on the ‚ÄúHello, I‚Äôm a Mac‚Äù intro to the old Apple ads. 
    

            ‚ÄúThese are all PCs,‚Äù Long says as he surveys a collection of laptops in the new ad. ‚ÄúOh yeah, Intel! Nice. My face just unlocked that, that‚Äôs so cool. And I‚Äôve never seen a screen like that on a laptop.‚Äù
    

            He moves on to look at the Mac lineup: ‚ÄúSo these are the newer Macs? Okay. So, gray and gray-er.‚Äù 
    

            The new commercial is the latest exchange of not-so-friendly fire between Intel and Apple in recent months. 
    

Related article
Apple brings back John Hodgman's hapless "PC" to troll new Mac features


            Last fall, Apple went from being an Intel customer to competitor when it replaced the semiconductor giant‚Äôs x86 chips with its own M1 chips in the newest Mac lineup. Apple claimed its new chipsmake Macs significantly faster and quieter and give them longer battery life compared to previous Mac models and rival laptops. 
    

            In fact, reviving the theme of the old Apple ads was the iPhone maker‚Äôs idea. When it announced the new M1 Macs in November, Apple brought back Hodgman to again star as ‚ÄúPC guy‚Äù in a new ad. 
    

            ‚ÄúHi, I‚Äôm a PC,‚Äù Hodgman says in Apple‚Äôs November ad. ‚ÄúIs there a time for questions? Good, because I have one. Why? Why make all these advancements? What‚Äôs the point?‚Äù
    

            Moves like Apple‚Äôs to make its own chips pose a real threat to Intel, which has long relied on dominating the PC business. In recent years, Intel has lost share in the PC market, among other challenges, and the company recently hired new CEO Pat Gelsinger to help right the ship. 
    

            At an Intel staff meeting in January, after Gelsinger was named the incoming CEO but before officially taking over the role, he told employees that the company has to ‚Äúdeliver better products‚Äù for PCs than anything ‚Äúa lifestyle company in Cupertino‚Äù makes, a likely reference to Apple, according to a report from The Oregonian.
    

            The new commercial may be another indicator of how aggressive Gelsinger plans to be in countering Apple and other competitors as he attempts to return Intel to its former glory. Whether the ad convinces people to buy more PCs remains to be seen, but at least Intel now has Long‚Äôs support.

            As the pandemic drags on, big chains like Target and Nordstrom are looking for ways to keep consumers coming back to their stores.
    

            One go-to strategy is the store-within-a-store concept. It‚Äôs a way for one retailer to join forces with another by setting up a pop-up shop within their stores. 
    

            Industry analysts saythe approach has benefits for both parties. For instance, department store Kohl‚Äôs
            
                (KSS) is adding as many as 200 Sephora mini shops inside of its stores in 2021 as a way to expand its beauty and cosmetics category. For Sephora, the deal helps the retailer expand its market to Kohl‚Äôs
            
                (KSS) shoppers.
    

            Meanwhile, Target is opening mini Apple shops in a handful of its stores as it strives to become a one-stop shop to meet all of its consumers‚Äô needs.
    

            ‚ÄúFrom Sephora co-locating in Kohl‚Äôs to Apple in Target stores, these collaborations bring complementary customer traffic and added income, especially for the host retailer,‚Äù said Burt Flickinger III, managing director of Strategic Resource Group. It‚Äôs also a way to get shoppers to visit stores more frequently, he said.
    

            ‚ÄúFor stores like Kohl‚Äôs or Nordstrom, shoppers maybe go once a month or once a quarter. By adding a store-in-a-store, now you can get a Kohl‚Äôs shopper returning more often for their beauty and cosmetics needs,‚Äù said Flickinger.
    

            A number of merchants have already joined forces. Here are a few of the most recent ‚Äúshop-in-shop‚Äù collaborations:
    

            Nordstrom and at-home fitness startup Tonal have teamed up to launch a handful of Tonal mini shops inside Nordstrom stores.
    

            The Tonal-branded pop-up stores are debuting this month in 40 Nordstrom locations across 20 states. The 50-square-foot shops will be located in the women‚Äôs activewear department. 
    

            Nordstrom said shoppers can see a demo of the gym or try a workout for themselves. 
    

            The home gym from San Francisco-based Tonal mounts to the wall like a flat screen television and uses ‚Äúdigital weights‚Äù where the resistance is personalized. The startup is backed by a slew of investors and athletes, including Stephen Curry of the Golden State Warriors.
    

            Industry analysts said the crossover appeal of this partnership is a good fit for consumers because Tonal‚Äôs pricey gyms could entice fans of Nordstrom, a chain considered to be high-end among its department store peers. The partnership also comes at a time when Nordstrom is battling sales declines and adapting its strategy to changing consumer preferences.
    

            ‚ÄúRetailers right now are looking for ways to boost customer traffic,‚Äù said Robert Passikoff, a retail industry expert and founder of consulting firm Brand Keys. ‚ÄúThe Nordstrom
            
                (JWN)-Tonal partnership makes sense because it fits well with the customers of both brands. For Tonal, it‚Äôs a very smart way to get its products in front of more consumers because everyone knows Nordstrom
            
                (JWN), so it will benefit from this sense of borrowed equity.‚Äù
    

            Makeup sales have been walloped by the pandemic. But that‚Äôs not stopping Sephora from adding more stores outside of struggling malls.
    

            Sephora is set to open mini shops inside Kohl‚Äôs
            
                (KSS) stores, with the first 200 locations debuting in fall of 2021.
    

            The partnership with Kohl‚Äôs will replace an earlier one that Sephora struck with JCPenney that is slated to end in the next few years.
    

            For Kohl‚Äôs, the collaboration allows it to attract younger consumers with wider array of beauty products and prices.
    

            ‚ÄúBeauty is an area where Kohl‚Äôs is currently underdeveloped, so it doesn‚Äôt capture much spend from shoppers who are already in its stores,‚Äù said Neil Saunders, retail industry analyst and managing director of GlobalData. ‚ÄúAdding a Sephora automatically resolves this issue, and it also makes Kohl‚Äôs a more interesting destination, which may help to drive foot traffic.‚Äù
    

            From Sephora‚Äôs perspective, Saunders said Kohl‚Äôs provides access to many off-mall locations where Sephora is currently underrepresented.
    

            Kohl‚Äôs expects to have as many as 850 ‚ÄúSephora at Kohl‚Äôs‚Äù shops in its stores by 2023, as well as an online shop later this year. 
    

            Target is opening scaled-down versions of Apple stores at some of its US locations this year.
    

            Target
            
                (TGT) said an ‚Äúenhanced Apple shopping experience‚Äù is rolling out to 17 stores in the coming months, with redesigned sections that include new lighting and displays for shoppers to experiment with an expanded assortment of Apple products.
    

            Target is also updating Apple
            
                (AAPL)‚Äôs product page on its app and website. Customers will still need to visit an actual Apple
            
                (AAPL) store for product repairs.
    

            Target is rolling out the new Apple mini-stores at five locations in Texas and four in Florida with the remaining scattered across various states, including New York, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania. The new Apple sections will be added to more Target stores in the coming years.
    

            It‚Äôs the latest high-profile partnership Target has struck as it continues to evolve into a one-stop destination for customers who are increasingly looking to avoid shopping at malls.
    

            Ulta Beauty is debuting its mini cosmetics shops inside of Target stores in 2021.
    

            As with Sephora‚Äôs mini shops in Kohl‚Äôs, this deal is expected to help Ulta
            
                (ULTA), which sells a mix of drugstore beauty and pricey brands that aren‚Äôt normally found in big box stores, reach younger and more budget-conscious consumers.
    

            For Target, it expands the retailer‚Äôs growing beauty business with new brands it didn‚Äôt carry before.
    

            The 1,000 square-foot mini shops will initially launch in 100 Target locations and on Target.com, and then ramping up to several hundred Target stores.
    

            ‚ÄúThe benefit for Ulta is increased exposure. Ulta has an incredibly successful track record and, before the pandemic, was posting consistently strong growth,‚Äù said Saunders.

            Apple made good on its ‚ÄúSpring loaded‚Äù promise by unveiling a slew of new products at its annual Spring product launch event.
    

            From a new IPad Pro and redesigned, colorful iMacs to a purple iPhone, the long-awaited AirTag location tracker, and an updated Apple TV and remote, here‚Äôs a closer look at everything Apple announced on Tuesday.
    

            As expected, Apple unveiled an updated iPad Pro with a faster processor, 5G support, a Thunderbolt port so it can connect to more external monitors, and a Mini-LED display.
    

            The display will reportedly increase brightness, offer a higher contrast ratio, and improve power efficiencies for a longer battery life.
    

            Apple is also adding its powerful M1 chip to its iPad Pro line, enabling several software updates including better graphics, enhanced video effects and augmented reality features.
    

            An updated camera allows enhanced depth and better quality video, and a feature called Center Stage that automatically zooms out during video calls or meetings, depending on the number of people in the frame.
    

            The new iPad Pro starts at $799 and is available for order starting April 30.
    

            Apple announced a redesigned iMac featuring the company‚Äôs new in-house M1 chip.
    

            The new chip allowed Apple to shrink the internal hardware ‚Äî building in a smaller logic board and replacing the thermal system that keeps the machine cool with two small fans. The new iMac is just 11.5 millimeters deep.
    

            The M1 chip will also make iMac apps run faster, improve the speed of machine learning and enable the use of iPhone apps such as Zillow and Headspace from the iMac screen, Apple execs said Tuesday.
    

            iMac will now have a 24-inch, 4.5 K display with 11.3 million pixels. And it comes in seven colors, including peach, mint and lavender.
    

            For users still working from home, Apple also improved the iMac‚Äôs camera. The 1080p camera‚Äôs features include auto white balance, noise reduction and tone mapping to make you look better. The computer also has a new mic designed to reduce feedback noise so you sound better, too.
    

            The new iMac starts at $1,299 for four colors, and $1,499 for the other three colors plus additional features. It will be available in the second half of May.
    

            Meanwhile, Apple is adding a touch ID button to the iMac‚Äôs external keyboard for the first time. The Touch ID button will be placed in the top right corner of the keyboard, like it is on the latest MacBooks, and will similarly let users unlock their computer, switch users or make payments through their fingerprints.
    

            Both the keyboard and Apple‚Äôs Magic Mouse will be available in a variety of colors to match with the new range of colors on the iMac.
    

            In what was Apple‚Äôs worst kept secret in recent history, the company finally unveiled AirTag, a Tile-like Bluetooth locator that attaches to and helps you find items such as keys, wallets, laptops or even your car.
    

            The small, flat, circular discs with built-in chips allow someone to locate items when connected to Apple‚Äôs Find My app. It also works with Siri.
    

            The stainless steel devices, which are water and dust resistant, feature a built-in speaker that plays sounds to help locate it. The AirTag is packed with the Apple-designed U1 chip, which uses Ultra Wideband technology ‚Äì the same chip used in the iPhone 12.
    

            While location trackers are hardly new ‚Äì there are similar products from Samsung, Sony and Tile ‚Äî the U1 chip will more accurately determine the distance and direction to a lost item, Apple says.
    

            Similar to Apple Watch, it‚Äôs possible to add free engraving to the device.
    

            An AirTag is $29 each or four for $99, starting April 30. Users can also splurge for leather accessories, such as key rings, luggage tags and a bag charm from Herm√®s.
    

            Apple is rolling out the next generation of its Apple TV 4K streaming device, along with a new Siri remote.
    

            The remote, made from what Apple says is 100% recycled aluminum, includes a new pad at the top that users can click or swipe through to navigate, as well as a dedicated Siri button on the side.
    

            The remote also has a dedicated power button to switch your TV on and off. The new Apple TV will be available starting April 30, with a 32 GB version for $179 and a 64 GB version for $199
    

            Apple also redesigned its podcast app, including a new section called channels that will curate shows.
    

            The company also made changes to its Apple Card offering for spouses and families who share their credit card accounts. 
    

            Spouses can now merge and share their Apple Card credit lines, while having equal rights on the account and with each person building credit. For families, the company will now allow any member over the age of 13 to use the family Apple Card account. Apple Card is an Apple-branded credit card issued by Goldman Sachs that the company launched in 2019, available only to iPhone users. 
    

            Apple also announced a paid service for podcasts called Apple Podcast Subscriptions. Among the perks of a podcast subscription will be ad-free listening, early access to new series and exclusive content. Some of the participating media brands include NPR, the Los Angeles Times and The Athletic. The paid service will be available in 170 regions and countries next month. Podcast creators set their own pricing. 
    

            In a bit of a surprise, Apple dedicated some stage time to announce that the iPhone 12 and iPhone 12 mini are now available in purple. This joins existing models available in blue, green, black, white and red. It starts at $799 and will go on sale April 30.

Title: Apple made a big mistake with its new iMacs

            Apple‚Äôs new iMac is awesome: a technical marvel and a culmination of Apple‚Äôs stunning engineering achievements over the past several years. It‚Äôs also ugly as sin.
    

            When Apple
            
                (AAPL) overdesigns its products, it‚Äôs typically for form over function. You know the list: getting rid of the headphone jack to make the iPhone thinner, ditching USB-A ports on MacBooks, switching the hinges on its keyboards‚Ä¶. They‚Äôre innovations that make Apple
            
                (AAPL)‚Äôs products look cool, but don‚Äôt make their products work any better.
    

            Strangely, Apple has chosen function over form with its new iMacs. 
    

            They‚Äôll work great: The 8-core M1 chip on a desktop computer is going to be ohmygod fast ‚Äî about twice as fast as the last iMac, Apple claims. The HD webcam, studio-grade microphones and surround-sound speakers are perfect for the Zoom era. Touch ID on the keyboard is a nice ‚Ä¶ touch.  The better-than-4K display is going to be *chef‚Äôs kiss.* 
    

            The only problem is you have to look at your new iMac when you‚Äôre using it.
    

            Ugh, those colors. It comes in Easter egg blue, green, yellow, pink, orange, purple and (thankfully) silver. If the colors weren‚Äôt bold enough, Apple added sorta faded complementary colors to the stand, which is an ‚Ä¶ interesting design choice.
    

            Even if you‚Äôre a pastel fan (or you wisely choose silver), you won‚Äôt be saved from the bizarre look of the new iMac. That weird chin that‚Äôs been a feature of the iMac since 2004 is still there, giving the new iMac a decidedly last-generation look. And the new version ditched the Apple logo, making that odd rectangle at the bottom of your screen look even stranger.
    

            It‚Äôs the kind of unforced error that Apple rarely makes. The M1 chip gave Apple a chance to completely rethink its iMac design. Instead, it chose to stick to the familiar shape, put the computer‚Äôs guts below the screen and make the iMac thinner. That comes with some advantages (more on that in a second), but the result is an aesthetic head-scratcher. 
    

Related article
Apple's iOS 14.5 update lands next week ‚Äî including new emojis, big privacy changes


            The worst feature of the new iMac is the bezel ‚Äî the white frame around the display.The chin makes the bezel really stand out. It was hardly noticeable in the past iMac iterations, because it was black. The white contrasts with the screen and the chin, giving the screen a seriously weird appearance. 
    

            It‚Äôs not 100% clear why Apple went this route, but the company left a few clues. 
    

            The new iMac is 11.5 millimeters thick, which is the thickness of about one and a half iPhone 12s. That‚Äôs insane. It comes with a magnetic power cable because you can move this thing around ‚Äî it weighs less than 10 pounds. The new iMac kind of blurs the lines between desktop and laptop.
    

            But how many people move their desktop computers so often that they need something that thin and light? And for those people, would a few millimeters of thickness and another pound make that much of a difference? 
    

            When you‚Äôre looking at your all-in-one desktop, how often are you really concerned about its thickness? The screen is the thing you‚Äôre staring at, which is why Apple should have maximized the screen real estate and minimized everything else. 
    

            Apple probably designed the iMac so thin because it could not because it should. The result, for a company that makes some of the most beautiful gadgets ever conceived, was a big swing and a miss ‚Äî something that looks like a cross between Jay Leno and an Easter egg.

            When people think Apple, they think big ticket items like iPhones, MacBooks and iPads. But the company‚Äôs accessories line of iPhone cases, chargers and tablet keyboards is a critical part of its revenue growth strategy. 
    

            Now AirTag could be its next big accessory win. 
    

            An AirTag is a Tile-like Bluetooth locator that attaches to and helps you find items such as keys, wallets, laptops or even your car. The small, flat, circular disc with a powerful built-in chip will allow someone to locate items when connected to Apple‚Äôs Find My app and also work with Siri.
    

            The stainless steel devices, which are water and dust resistant, feature a built-in speaker that plays sounds to better locate an AirTag. It‚Äôs packed with the Apple-designed U1 chip, which uses Ultra Wideband technology ‚Äì the same chip used in the iPhone 12. 
    

            While location trackers are hardly new ‚Äì there are similar products from Samsung, Sony and Tile ‚Äì the U1 chip will allow it to more accurately determine the distance and direction to a lost item. It also works with augmented reality, showing an animation on the screen of the user‚Äôs iPhone or iPad when nearby. 
    

            AirTag has been reportedly in the works as far back as 2019, when pictures hidden within iOS 13 were discovered.
    

            AirTag costs $29 for each or $99 for four, starting April 30. Users can also splurge for leather accessories, such as key rings, luggage tags and a bag charm from Herm√®s. Similar to Apple Watch, it‚Äôs possible to add free engraving to the device.
    

            ‚ÄúApple accessories are very important from a business perspective because they tend to be high-margin products,‚Äù said Ben Stanton, senior analyst at tech market research firm Canalys. ‚ÄúSo while accessories may not make headlines from a revenue perspective, they do have a particularly positive impact on profitability.‚Äù
    

Related article
What to expect at Apple's 'Spring loaded' event


            The arrival of AirTag will allow the company to expand its offerings and lock users deeper into its ecosystem as it looks for more ways to take on an expected decline in its hardware revenues. The iPhone continued to dominate Apple‚Äôs revenue in the fourth quarter of 2020, accounting for 59% of sales, compared to 12% for its accessories category, which also includes wearables and its Home line. However, the accessories category amounts to more revenue than its Mac line.
    

            Still, Apple accessories remain a massive opportunity for upselling. Because Apple no longer includes a charger and cable in iPhone boxes upon purchase, demand for these items has surged in the past year. ‚ÄúApple itself has seen supply shortages of charging accessories in some parts of the world, causing many customers and retailers to lean heavily on third-party alternatives,‚Äù said Stanton, citing anecdotes he‚Äôs heard from several distributors. 
    

            In addition, the company‚Äôs smart Magic Keyboard and the Apple Pencil opens up new revenue streams as lower-cost iPad users look for more functionality. 
    

            ‚ÄúAlthough AirTags are probably going to be fairly low priced, they may help to grow revenue, and users may buy multiple tags for different scenarios, such as for a bag, bike or car keys,‚Äù said David McQueen, director at tech market advisory firm, ABI Research. ‚ÄúIt may also spark a rise in the manufacture of accessories to house the tags, such as a key fob, keychain or wrist strap.‚Äù
    

            Customers who are delaying costly smartphone and tablet upgrades may be willing to spend more on lower cost items such as these. 
    

            It‚Äôs a smart time for their launch as customers are finally emerging from over a year of lockdown ‚Äî ready, perhaps, to find things people invariably lose when outside the house.

            If the ‚ÄúSpring loaded‚Äù tagline of Apple‚Äôs upcoming press event is any indication, the company is about to drop a ton of new products.

            The invitations for the virtual press conference sent to reporters last week included an image of colorful spirals that form the Apple logo ‚Äî a picture potentially made to look as if it had been produced by an Apple Pencil, a clue hinting at updates to its iPad line. 
    

            The company‚Äôs invitations are often filled with red herrings, but Apple senior marketing executive Greg Joswiak added to the fodder when he tweeted a video featuring an animation of the spirals bouncing around Apple‚Äôs campus. It sparked speculation that augmented reality could also be part of the company‚Äôs presentation.
    

            Apple is expected to show off an updated iPad Pro with a faster processor, 5G support, a Thunderbolt port so it can connect to more external monitors and a Mini LED display. 
    

            The display will reportedly increase brightness, offer a higher contrast ratio, improve power efficiencies for a longer battery life but be slightly thicker than current versions. It‚Äôs possible Apple will also show off a redesigned iPad mini with smaller bezels and a larger display. But it‚Äôs unclear if any of these updates will be enough to convince users to upgrade.
    

            Eleftheria Kouri, an analyst at tech market advisory firm ABI Research, said tablet shipments significantly increased in 2020, thanks in part to remote learning and working. But that uptick won‚Äôt last forever. ‚ÄúTablet vendors, including Apple, need to introduce a really game changing technological feature in order to boost sales and encourage consumers to replace their old devices: 5G connectivity is one of these key features,‚Äù she said.

            This is where AR could come into play. In iOS 13, a string of code stated: ‚ÄúWalk around several feet and move your ‚ÄåiPhone‚Äå up and down until a balloon comes into view,‚Äù indicating where an item may be hiding, according to MacRumors. 
    

            Not only is the Apple TV due for a new processor and better refresh support for gaming, a redesigned remote could work as a physical locator for AirTags, according to tech blog 9to5Mac.
    

            And then there‚Äôs AirPods 3. The next-generation of Apple‚Äôs wireless earbuds are believed to have a design more in line with its higher-end AirPods Pro, along with spatial audio support and touch controls. AirPods have cultivated a cult-like following over the years and emerged as a fashion and status symbol, but it‚Äôs possible Apple could wait until later this year to show off a new model. 
    

            Apple‚Äôs MacBook Pro and MacBook Air are also due for refreshes, but it‚Äôs unclear if they‚Äôll get one as early as next week. Apple recently discontinued its iMac Pro line, once the most-powerful computer the company offered, and its original HomePod to focus more on the HomePod mini.
    

            The company could also walk users through an expected iOS 14.5 software update focused on privacy. Its upcoming App Tracking Transparency feature will require app developers to explicitly divulge how they‚Äôre collecting user data, what it‚Äôll be used for, and require user consent before they download or update apps from the App Store.
    

            Still, all eyes will be on the lookout for new gadgets on Tuesday. ‚ÄúDespite the disruptions in the production line, crisis in the semiconductor industry and economic uncertainty that was caused by pandemic, demand for consumer products generally remained resilient,‚Äù said Kouri. 
    

            ABI Research expects demand for certain products, such as true wireless earbuds and 5G devices, will see explosive growth the coming years, but tech companies like Apple will first have to provide enough incentive for consumers to spend their dollars.

            When Apple unveiled its colorful new iMac line at a virtual product launch earlier this week, reactions were divided: They‚Äôre beautiful. They‚Äôre ugly. What is with that ‚Äòchin‚Äô? 
    

            The event was one of the most exciting product launches from any tech company in a while. Apple
            
                (AAPL) introduced an entirely new product ‚Äî its AirTag location trackers ‚Äî updated iPads, a revamped Apple
            
                (AAPL) TV, and the biggest design change to the iMac in years. 
    

            After being stuck inside for over a year, staring at lackluster computer screens, the iMac‚Äôs new look and vibrant colors are a breath of fresh air.
    

            Now at only 11.5 millimeters deep and just 10 pounds, the iMac resembles an iPad on a stand more than a standard computer. The desktop computer is so thin that Apple moved the headphone jack to the side of the display; it no longer fits in the back because that is now deeper than the screen itself. 
    

            The company‚Äôs new in-house M1 chip ‚Äì a processor that will make everything run twice as fast as its predecessor ‚Äì is tucked into what people have come to refer to as the chin, or the white frame that sits just below the screen. The previous iMac also featured a chin but had a large logic board and thermals due in part to its power-hungry processor, and other components such as CPU and GPU were separately located in the system. 
    

            Now with M1, everything is consolidated into a much smaller logic board. Conceivably, Apple could have sacrificed some thinness to eliminate the chin.
    

            Many people criticized the decision, calling the chin distracting and unbalanced with the rest of the screen. Memes circulated of what a similar design would look like on an iPhone.
    

            ‚ÄúApple made a clear choice around the chin and it was the thin design that was front and center for this iMac design,‚Äù said Dan Ives, a director at investment firm Wedbush. ‚ÄúIt is focused on creating a uniquely thin iMac, and for Apple, it‚Äôs about a 360 degree view, which is why the design team decided not to put the internals in the back.‚Äù
    

Related article
Apple made a big mistake with its new iMacs


            While some believe Apple could introduce a screen with less of a bezel in the months ahead, along with more traditional colors, its move to push out a bold design now with equally bold colors draws attention to the line, potentially encouraging more people to upgrade from their existing computers.
    

            Michael Heilemann, principal designer at website building and hosting company Squarespace, was among some designers who defended the Apple‚Äôs changes. ‚ÄúThe new iMac makes it a statement again,‚Äù Heilemann told CNN Business. ‚ÄúComputers aren‚Äôt just for spreadsheets or for tucking in the drawer when you‚Äôre done. They can be a part of your identity same as your clothes and your furniture. You use them just as much, so why not? 
    

            ‚ÄúThe thin, sleek design also means that even though it‚Äôs colorful and loud, it feels elegant,‚Äù he added.
    

            Rather than the space grays and whites of its usual color wheel, the new lineup offers iMacs in red, orange, yellow, blue, green, purple and silver. Both the keyboard and Apple‚Äôs Magic Mouse will be available in a variety of colors, too.
    

            Each color was hidden in the event‚Äôs press invitations, which are often filled with red herrings, and showed up again in the video at the start of the keynote featuring CEO Tim Cook. In the clip, an animation of colorful spirals bounced about Apple‚Äôs campus, ultimately forming the word ‚Äúhello,‚Äù a reference that goes back to the very first Mac. It feels like a throwback to how Apple experimented with colors and a few patterns in the iMacs‚Äô early days, as it looked for ways to stand out.
    

            ‚ÄúUp until the first iMac, they were at best inoffensive, trying to make the best of being an office appliance,‚Äù said Heilemann. ‚ÄúThe iMac changed that and made it something people could have in their homes and not feel like it brought the office home with them.‚Äù
    

            Over time, Apple left the colors and eccentricities behind in favor of a more minimalistic, industrial design.
    

            While it‚Äôs unusual for desktops to come in so many colors, Ross Rubin, a principal analyst at Reticle Research, noted other companies have tried to stand out in different ways in recent years. HP‚Äôs all-in-one computer comes with a panoramic wide screen, Lenovo introduced one that rotates 90 degrees, and Microsoft‚Äôs Surface Desktop can be pulled down and forward to the point where it can be worked on as a tablet.
    

            ‚ÄúBut the design of the iMac is striking,‚Äù Rubin said. ‚ÄúIt will be difficult for PC makers to match that level of thinness for awhile unless they start leveraging ARM chips that they have used only in laptops up to this point.‚Äù
    

            Although the pandemic renewed interest in desktops as more people worked from home, it‚Äôs uncertain if the demand will continue as Covid-19 vaccines roll out and economies reopen. Still, it‚Äôs refreshing to see Apple, perhaps, thinking differently yet again.

            I clipped a keychain with one of Apple‚Äôs tiny new Bluetooth trackers, AirTags, onto my son‚Äôs book bag and waved goodbye to him on the school bus. I watched on my iPhone‚Äôs Find My app as the bus stopped at a light a few blocks down from our street.
    

            But then the tiny ‚Äúkey‚Äù icon on the app stopped moving. The item was ‚Äúlast detected‚Äù seven minutes ago at a busy intersection less than a mile away. Traffic, maybe? Five more minutes passed with no update. Is there an issue with the app? After another 10 minutes, my heart started to race; still nothing.
    

            Finally, the tracker was detected four miles away in front of his school. Relieved, I decided more information in this case was worse; I‚Äôd go back to just tracking my keys. Apple later told me the delay was due to the tracker needing to communicate with Bluetooth on other iOS devices in the Find My network along the bus route before the AirTag‚Äôs location could be updated to iCloud and the app.
    

            Still, my experiment highlighted how easily these trackers could be used to track another person. After all, I knew the moment he arrived at school and when he got back on the bus to head home.
    

            Earlier this month, Apple
            
                (AAPL) launched $29 Tile-like Bluetooth locators that attach to and help you find items such as keys, wallets, laptops or your car, giving nearly anything a digital footprint. Location trackers aren‚Äôt new ‚Äî there are similar products from Samsung, Sony and Tile ‚Äî but AirTags‚Äô powerful Ultra Wideband technology chip allows it to more accurately determine the location and enables precise augmented reality directional arrows that populate on the iPhone or iPad‚Äôs screen.
    

            While AirTags are explicitly intended for items only, Apple has added safeguards to cut down on unwanted tracking. For example, the company does not store location data, and it will send an alert to an iOS device user if an AirTag appears to be following them when its owner is not around. If the AirTag doesn‚Äôt re-tether to the owner‚Äôs iOS device after three days, the tracker will start to make a noise.
    

            ‚ÄúWe take customer safety very seriously and are committed to AirTag‚Äôs privacy and security,‚Äù the company said in a statement to CNN Business. ‚ÄúAirTag is designed with a set of proactive features to discourage unwanted tracking‚Äî a first in the industry‚Äî and the Find My network includes a smart, tunable system with deterrents that applies to AirTag, as well as third-party products part of the Find My network accessory program. We are raising the bar on privacy for our users and the industry, and hope others will follow.‚Äù
    

            The safeguards are a work in progress as the software rolls out and users begin interacting with the devices. When my babysitter recently took my son to an appointment, using my set of keys with an AirTag attached, she was not informed that she wascarrying anAirTag ‚Äî separated from my phone. (She hadn‚Äôt yet updated her phone‚Äôs software to iOS 14.5.) 
    

            Non-iPhone users can hold their phones close to the AirTags and, via short-range wireless technology, information pops up on how to disable the tracker, but that‚Äôs if the person knows they‚Äôre being tracked and locates it. In addition, three days is a long time for an AirTag to keep quiet before making a noise.
    

            Apple told CNN Business it may adjust these features through software updates to improve the AirTags‚Äô tracking deterrents. It also said the three-day alert window was determined so as to not inundate users with alerts. For example, if a spouse puts an AirTag on a gym bag and leaves it in a closet while at work, whoever is at home may consider the noise a nuisance.  
    

            Despite the safeguards, some privacy experts and groups are still concerned about unwanted tracking. For example, the National Network to End Domestic Violence ‚Äî which sits on advisory boards of tech companies including Facebook and Uber ‚Äî has been vocal about how AirTag and similar devices could be used by an abuser to discreetly monitor someone‚Äôs whereabouts.
    

            ‚ÄúAbusive individuals will misuse any type of technology as a tactic of abuse, regardless of the intended purpose or how helpful it can be to someone else,‚Äù Erica Olsen, safety net project director at NNEDV, told CNN Business. ‚ÄúLocation tracking is very common and a significant concern for survivors, but this isn‚Äôt specific just to AirTags. Apple‚Äôs privacy and security notifications can actually make this device harder for abusive people to misuse than others on the market and that point shouldn‚Äôt be lost.‚Äù
    

            However, she said more work needs to be done to ‚Äúmaximize privacy.‚Äù
    

            Albert Fox Cahn, founder and executive director of the Surveillance Technology Oversight Project and a fellow at the NYU School of Law, agreed, saying AirTag‚Äôs safeguards ‚Äúdon‚Äôt go far enough.‚Äù
    

Related article
AirTag could give a nice bump to Apple's growing lineup of smaller stuff 


            ‚ÄúThree days of tracking is more than long enough to create a privacy risk. For those living with their abusers, they might never find out they‚Äôre being tracked if their abusers can frequently come within range of the AirTag,‚Äù Cahn said. ‚ÄúSimilarly, it is helpful that AirTags will alert nearby iPhones to their presence, but those using Android won‚Äôt receive an alert if an AirTag is tracking them.‚Äù 
    

            Apple said one of the main reasons it spent so much time developing safeguards was the sheer size of its Find My app network. But it‚Äôs the AirTags‚Äô reliance on that broader network that creates much of the need for the safeguards in the first place, Cahn said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs because Apple is turning more than a billion iOS devices into a network for tracking AirTags, while Tile will only operate when in range of the small number of people using the Tile app. ‚Ä¶ The benefits of finding our keys a bit quicker isn‚Äôt worth the danger of creating a new global tracking network.‚Äù
    

            Although AirTags launched just last week, tech analysts already believe the trackers could be the next big accessory win for Apple. Accessories ‚Äî from iPhone cases and chargers to tablet keyboards ‚Äî are a critical part of its revenue growth strategy. 
    

            But as AirTag adoption grows, Ramon Llamas, a director at research firm IDC, echoed that Apple will need to expand its safeguards, as nefarious parties will ‚Äúfind a way to get around privacy issues one way or another.‚Äù
    

            ‚ÄúThis is a work in progress, especially as the use case continues to evolve,‚Äù Llamas said. ‚ÄúFor now, AirTags is intended for items.‚Äù

Title: AirTag vs. Tile Mate: How to pick the right tracker for you
Apple's rivals may never be able to catch up to its powerful new chip
Content:

            Early in the testing phase of Apple‚Äôs M1 chipset, a milestone new product for the company, the processor was installed in a batch of Mac computers and given to staffers working on applications that demanded heavy processing power. It was a pivotal moment: the first time Apple had made its own chip for any of its computers, shifting away from years of using a one-size-fits-all option from Intel.
    

            After multiple teams tested the devices for a few hours while working on tasks, they reported lightning-fast performance but nearly all flagged an apparent problem. The MacBook Pro‚Äôs battery indicator, featured on the upper right hand corner of the computers, was broken. It had barely moved despite running power-hungry programs, the company told CNN Business.
    

            The gag, of course, is that the battery indicator was working just fine. The M1 chip was so efficient, according to Apple, that it showed no real strain ‚Äì one of several major selling points for products that now carry the chip. (Apple promises 20 hours of battery life for its 13-inch M1 MacBook Pro ‚Äì what it says is the longest battery in any Mac to date). 
    

            Apple also claims the M1 offers the world‚Äôs fastest CPU core and fastest integrated graphics in a personal computer, with 3.5 times faster performance, up to 6 times faster graphics processing and 15 times faster machine learning compared to previous-generation Macs. 
    

            On Friday, the company launched its first iMac desktop and iPad Pro line with M1 (the M1 MacBook Air, 13-inch MacBook Pro and Mac mini shipped late last year). Early reviews applauded the latest models for unmatched performance speeds, long-lasting batteries and better graphics, all due in part to the processor.
    

            For the iMac specifically, the design is also a technical feat: Because the M1 is so efficient, Apple was able to tuck two compact fans into the computer screen rather than an elaborate, bigger cooling system. The components were ultimately squeezed inside a smaller logic board so the entire computer measures just 11.5 millimeters deep. 
    

            Some PC makers may now be weighing the pros and cons of trying to keep up with the M1. Most rivals, including Samsung, rely on third-party processors from companies such as Intel, AMD, and Qualcomm ‚Äì options that are manufactured to fit many different computer models. Apple‚Äôs tailor-made M1 promises performance far better than competitors. (Intel recently ran performance tests of its Gen Core i7 processor that beat the M1 in certain areas, including Chrome browsing and Microsoft Office 365 tasks. One tech publication, however, called the range ‚Äúcherry picked‚Äù to favor Intel‚Äôs chips.)
    

            ‚ÄúThe main reason it‚Äôll take other PC vendors a while to catch up to Apple is because most of them don‚Äôt control the whole stack of hardware and software,‚Äù said Jitesh Ubrani, a research manager at market research firm IDC. ‚ÄúThis tight integration between the two is Apple‚Äôs main advantage.‚Äù
    

            Apple is in a rare situation. Its design architects know which products are coming down the pipeline and which features, thermal cooling systems and other components its chips will need to support. It‚Äôs also not building and selling chips to different companies for countless products, so it doesn‚Äôt have the design considerations or trade-offs of building something more generic. 
    

Related article
No, the new iMac isn't ugly. The design and colors are a breath of fresh air


            CEO Tim Cook alluded to this at Apple‚Äôs Worldwide Developer Conference in June last year. ‚ÄúWhen we make changes, it‚Äôs for one simple but powerful reason: so we can make much better products,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWhen we look ahead, we envision some amazing new products that transitioning to our custom silicon will enable us to bring to life.‚Äù
    

            Beyond performance, for example, the chip could help enable the development of better cameras, providing more support for image signal processors.
    

            The effort to move to its own silicon ‚Äì a term referencing the core semiconductor components used in computing devices ‚Äì has been years in the making. Apple has been acquiring small semiconductor design teams and hiring semiconductor architecture designers for well over a decade.
    

            Apple‚Äôs rivals may be more constrained. There are rumors Samsung is working on a Windows notebook with Exynos, an ARM-based chip manufactured by Samsung. But unlike Apple, Ubrani argues that Samsung ‚Äúwouldn‚Äôt have the chops‚Äù to make chips comparable to the M1 without input from Microsoft.
    

            Microsoft, meanwhile, is in a particularly tough spot as it has to ensure Windows remains compatible with multiple chip manufacturers and gives users support for legacy apps, he said.
    

            With business already booming, not every PC maker is looking to invest in chasing M1. 
    

            ‚ÄúThe majority of PC vendors are actually in a pretty good position right now, with demand remaining strong as we‚Äôve moved into 2021,‚Äù said Ishan Dutt, an analyst for market research firm Canalys. The market for PCs, excluding tablets, is expected to grow around 13% this year on top of a stellar 2020, according to Canalys. 
    

            Samsung, for example, has seen its PC business do well in recent quarters due to demand stemming from the pandemic, especially for its Chromebook line. ‚ÄúThere isn‚Äôt much of a pressing need to do a dramatic overhaul of its portfolio without evidence that it would substantially improve their position in the market,‚Äù he said.
    

            Dutt argued Samsung may also not try to touch the M1 because laptops and desktops are a smaller product category for the company, and the costs and potential risks of revamping its lineup are high compared to the upside. ‚ÄúApple was keen to wean themselves off reliance on Intel in order to reduce some of the friction it was facing and exert greater control over the end-to-end design of its devices,‚Äù he said.
    

            Samsung wouldn‚Äôt be alone in shying away from the investment. According to Ben Bajarin, principal analyst at Creative Strategies, ‚ÄúMost companies will not make their own silicon as it is extremely expensive.‚Äù 
    

            But the cost clearly isn‚Äôt stopping Apple. The company previously said in a press release that M1 is the start of a new family of chips designed specifically for the Mac.‚Äù Future iterations will serve as an insurance policy for future Apple innovation.

Title: Tim Cook will make first-ever court appearance as Apple CEO in blockbuster Fortnite trial
Content:

            Tim Cook has fielded questions from Congress about Apple‚Äôs market power. Now he‚Äôs about to be grilled on it for the first time in federal court.
    

            The iPhone maker‚Äôs chief executive is set to take the stand Friday morning as the company‚Äôs high-profile antitrust trial with Epic Games nears an end.
    

            At the center of the lawsuit is Fortnite, the hugely popular video game made by Epic that was kicked out of Apple
            
                (AAPL)‚Äôs App Store last summer for flouting Apple
            
                (AAPL)‚Äôs rules on digital payments by establishing its own system. Apple
            
                (AAPL) gets a 30% cut of many in-app purchases on iOS devices and does not allow alternative payment systems. Fortnite‚Äôs removal from the App Store prompted Epic to sue Apple
            
                (AAPL).
    

            Epic accuses Apple of exercising monopolistic control over its ‚Äúwalled garden‚Äù iOS operating system, with app makers forced into its onerous restrictions if they want access to hundreds of millions of iPhone and iPad users. Apple argues there are several other places users can buy apps and that its commission helps the company make its devices better and more secure.
    

Related article
Epic Games and Apple spar over consoles and walled gardens on opening day of trial


            Several executives from both sides have already testified, including Craig Federighi, Apple‚Äôs senior vice president of software engineering, and Phil Schiller, Apple Fellow and former longtime head of marketing, who each took the stand earlier this week. Epic Games CEO Tim Sweeney was the first witness in the trial, which has lasted nearly three weeks and is scheduled to wrap up on Monday. 
    

            For Cook and Apple, there‚Äôs more at stake than just this blockbuster court case. Cook‚Äôs testimony on Friday is likely to set the tone for Apple‚Äôs fight against the growing antitrust pressure it‚Äôs facing. Other frenemies such as Spotify and Match Group, the owner of Tinder, have accused the App Store of being anticompetitive. And regulators in several countries, including the United States and the United Kingdom, have launched investigations into Apple‚Äôs rules. 
    

            Despite his multiple congressional testimonies and many public appearances and interviews, Cook appears to be preparing extensively for his day in court. He has undergone several hours of mock questioning from former prosecutors to mimic what he might face on the stand, according to a report from the Wall Street Journal.
    

            ‚ÄúThe thing that‚Äôs got to be a little bit scary to Epic is that Tim Cook by reputation is a very persuasive witness,‚Äù said Herbert Hovenkamp, a professor of legal studies and business ethics at the University of Pennsylvania‚Äôs Wharton School of Business. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs doing what he was hired to do, which is make Apple‚Äôs case to the public.‚Äù
    

            According to the witness list provided to the court, Cook will talk about ‚ÄúApple‚Äôs corporate values; Apple‚Äôs business and operations; development and launch of the App Store; competition faced by Apple.‚Äù An Apple representative said Cook will likely expand on his personal views about security and privacy ‚Äî issues he has previously used to criticize other large tech companies ‚Äî and their importance to Apple‚Äôs product philosophy. 
    

            Cook is expected to pull together and buttress arguments that Apple‚Äôs lawyers, experts and other executives have made throughout the trial ‚Äî that the iPhone‚Äôs App Store doesn‚Äôt constitute a monopoly. The company says that the 30% commission it takes on transactions within apps isn‚Äôt illegal and helps make Apple devices better and more secure, as does the tight control it exercises over the apps on those devices.
    

            In his testimony, Schiller highlighted how much Apple spends on research and development ‚Äî an estimated $100 billion over the last 15 years ‚Äî to make product improvements that developers can piggyback off of.
    

            He also sought to push back against Epic‚Äôs effort to paint Apple as a monopolist. The gaming company says Apple forces developers to play by burdensome rules such as only using its App Store and in-app payment methods if they want access to more than a billion iPhone and iPad users. (Michael Schmid, Apple‚Äôs head of games business development for the App Store, revealed on the stand that Apple has made more than $100 million in commissions from Fortnite.)
    

            Schiller ticked off a list of competitors for both mobile devices and app stores ‚Äî Google, Samsung, Motorola, Huawei and even gaming consoles such as the Sony PlayStation, Microsoft Xbox and Nintendo Switch. Apple argues that many of them also take a 30% commission and have similar restrictions on outside apps. 
    

            ‚ÄúThere are many, many competitors for app distribution,‚Äù he said. 
    

Related article
Apple will slash App Store fees as antitrust pressure mounts


            Federighi, the company‚Äôs software chief, stressed the importance of Apple‚Äôs security protections for its iOS mobile operating system ‚Äî even criticizing its MacOS computer system in the process. 
    

            Unlike the iPhone, the Mac allows outside app stores and app downloads, a process known as ‚Äúside-loading.‚Äù Epic has repeatedly pointed to and called on Apple to emulate this approach for its mobile devices. But Apple‚Äôs lawyers and executives argue the iPhone needs the extra protection because of the sheer number of devices that can be exploited, the fact that smartphones are with users virtually all the time, and hold more sensitive personal data. 
    

            ‚ÄúIf you took Mac security techniques and applied them to the iOS ecosystem, with all those devices, all that value, it would get run over to a degree dramatically worse than is already happening on the Mac,‚Äù Federighi said. ‚ÄúWe have a level of malware on the Mac that we don‚Äôt find acceptable, and that is much worse than iOS.‚Äù 
    

            Cook is not expected to deviate much from those arguments, according to Florian Ederer, a professor of economics at the Yale School of Management. ‚ÄúIt is unlikely that any new information or new argument will come from his testimony that has not already been brought to the judge‚Äôs attention,‚Äù Ederer said. 
    

            ‚ÄúPutting Cook on the stand is essentially the best way for Apple to signal to the judge that it is taking this case seriously,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúIf anything, putting Cook on the stand just shows respect for the proceedings.‚Äù

Title: Apple TV+ announces Oprah Winfrey and Prince Harry series debut date
Content:
A highly anticipated multi-part documentary series from co-creators and executive producers Oprah Winfrey and Prince Harry, The Duke of Sussex, now has a debut date.
    

            Apple TV+ announced Monday that ‚ÄúThe Me You Can‚Äôt See,‚Äù which features stories meant to help lift the veil on the current state of mental health and emotional well-being, will premiere May 21 on Apple TV+. 
    

            According to a news release about the series, ‚ÄúOprah Winfrey and Prince Harry guide honest discussions about mental health and emotional well-being while opening up about their mental health journeys and struggles,‚Äù 
    

            ‚ÄúFeaturing high-profile guests, alongside a wide range of people from across the globe living with the challenges of mental health issues and addressing their emotional well-being, the series transcends culture, age, gender, and socioeconomic status to destigmatize a highly misunderstood subject and give hope to viewers who learn that they are not alone.‚Äù the release reads. ‚ÄúThe producers partnered with 14 accredited and respected experts and organizations from around the world to help shed light on different pathways to treatment.‚Äù
    

            ‚ÄúNow more than ever, there is an immediate need to replace the shame surrounding mental health with wisdom, compassion, and honesty,‚Äù Winfrey said in a statement. ‚ÄúOur series aims to spark that global conversation.‚Äù
    

            ‚ÄúWe are born into different lives, brought up in different environments, and as a result are exposed to different experiences. But our shared experience is that we are all human,‚Äù Prince Harry, The Duke of Sussex, said. ‚ÄúThe majority of us carry some form of unresolved trauma, loss, or grief, which feels ‚Äì and is ‚Äì very personal. Yet the last year has shown us that we are all in this together, and my hope is that this series will show there is power in vulnerability, connection in empathy, and strength in honesty.‚Äù

Title: Apple and Epic Games spar in closing arguments over Fortnite
Content:
Markets 



Hot Stocks 



Fear & Greed Index

            A weeks-long blockbuster antitrust trial between Apple and Epic Games culminated on Monday with the maker of the hit video game Fortnite calling Apple an ‚Äúoverlord‚Äù and the iPhone maker suggesting Epic is paving the way for a ‚Äúscary‚Äù future for iOS customers.
    

            After spending days presenting reams of dueling economic analysis and documentary evidence, the two sides landed on Monday where they began: arguing over how Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers should interpret Apple‚Äôs role in a sprawling digital economy. The outcome of that analysis could reshape how digital app stores work or uphold Apple‚Äôs prime position in its app ecosystem.
    

            In a matter of weeks, Gonzalez Rogers is set to decide whether Apple is an agile innovator that reaped just rewards for building a popular app business, or if it is, as Epic alleges, a monopolist that uses its control over the iOS App Store to illegally harm competition, restrict innovation and keep prices high. 
    

            Wrapping up the three-week trial, which saw top executives including Apple CEO Tim Cook and Epic CEO Tim Sweeney called in for questioning, the judge said Monday she will strive to issue an opinion by mid-August, though it could take longer given the thousands of pages generated by the groundbreaking antitrust case. 
    

            Epic has arguedApple‚Äôs walled-garden ecosystem makes it impossible to download iPhone and iPad apps from anywhere but Apple‚Äôs own app store, making Apple a monopoly owner. That allegedmonopoly creates opportunities for Apple to impose restrictive terms on iOS app makers, Epic claims, such as requiring a 30% cut of all in-app sales of digital goods and services. (Fortnite was kicked out of Apple‚Äôs App Store last summer for flouting Apple‚Äôs rules on digital payments by directing players to its own, outside system.)
    

Related article
Epic Games and Apple spar over consoles and walled gardens on opening day of trial


            On Monday, Epic pleaded with Gonzalez Rogers for an order banning Apple from implementing some of its policies and forcing Apple to allow third-party app stores to compete with its own proprietary app store. Epic also accused Apple of trying to convince the judge it is a ‚Äúbenevolent overlord‚Äù of the iOS ecosystem thatshould be allowed to continue to operate without competition ‚Äúbecause it‚Äôs worked out okay so far.‚Äù
    

            ‚ÄúThat is not a defense under the antitrust laws,‚Äù Epic‚Äôs lawyer said. (When Gonzalez Rogers pointed out that Apple couldn‚Äôt be ‚Äúbenevolent‚Äù while also being anti-competitive, Epic‚Äôs lawyer disagreed and said Apple was only ‚Äúpretending to be a benevolent overlord‚Äù and needed to be genuinely tested against competitors.)
    

            By contrast, Apple has urged Gonzalez Rogers to consider the company‚Äôs App Store as part of a vibrant, competitive market for video game sales. A procession of prominent executives, culminating with Cook on Friday, argued that Apple‚Äôs platform rules protect users and provide security and privacy. And on Monday, its lawyers said that giving Epic whatit wants would be unjustified and unprecedented. 
    

            Gonzalez Rogers offered critical questions to both sides. She challenged Apple on its commission structure, pointing out that ‚Äúif there was real competition, that number would move and it hasn‚Äôt.‚Äù Apple argued later that it has reduced commissions several times, such as by creating a discount for small businesses. 
    

            At certain points, the judge implied she was open to finding that Apple had broken the law, musing hypothetically about potential restrictions she could impose on Apple under California law, or considering an analysis that could allow for a finding of anticompetitive conduct by Apple without deciding that it holds a monopoly. 
    

            In a somewhat tense exchange, Gonzalez Rogers grilled Cook after his testimony on Friday, asking why Apple couldn‚Äôt give users a choice to get games and content cheaper than it is on the iPhone. She also asked why Apple wouldn‚Äôt let apps tell users they could pay for in-app content more cheaply elsewhere online ‚Äî a point she hit on again Monday. 
    

Related article
Tim Cook defends Apple in blockbuster Fortnite trial: 'It has nothing to do with money'


            She also pushed hard against Epic on Monday, suggesting that what the company was asking her to do was to ‚Äúchange the business model‚Äù of Apple. She challenged Epic‚Äôs lawyer, Gary Bornstein, to cite an example of a case that had ended in that type of outcome involving private litigants. The attorneys briefly debated the landmark Microsoft antitrust case of the 1990s, the US government‚Äôs recent case against Qualcomm and a pending Supreme Court case before ultimately rejecting them as appropriate comparisons. 
    

            ‚ÄúYou haven‚Äôt told me a single antitrust case where the kind of relief you are requesting has been granted by a court when a private plaintiff comes in,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt is a pretty significant step that courts haven‚Äôt done.‚Äù (Bornstein admitted he did not have a perfect analogy onhand and that the judge faces ‚Äúa pretty unique situation.‚Äù)
    

            By expressing reservations about precedent, Gonzalez Rogers opened the door to arguments by Apple that giving into Epic‚Äôs requests would represent a serious break from history. 
    

            ‚ÄúIf that is scary for Apple‚Äôs iOS customers ‚Ä¶ and for this court, that is simply a consequence of what Epic is asking for,‚Äù said Apple‚Äôs lawyer, Richard Doren. In contrast, Epic claimed that Apple is attempting to ‚Äúscare the court.‚Äù 
    

            But at other times, Gonzalez Rogers appeared to relish her role on the cutting edge of the law. 
    

            ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt call us the Wild West for nothing,‚Äù she joked.

Title: Apple parts ways with newly hired ex-Facebook employee after workers cite 'misogynistic' writing
Content:

            Apple parted ways with a new employee this week after thousands of workers petitioned the company to investigate how it hired the man, who had previously published an autobiography they said contains misogynistic statements.
    

            Antonio Garc√≠a Mart√≠nez, formerly a product manager for ad targeting at Facebook as well as the author of the 2016 autobiography ‚ÄúChaos Monkeys: Obscene Fortune and Random Failure in Silicon Valley,‚Äù joined Apple‚Äôs ads team in April, according to his LinkedIn profile. 
    

            Garc√≠a Mart√≠nez‚Äôs book chronicles his life in the San Francisco Bay Area‚Äôs tech scene from 2010 to 2014. He began his career as a quantitative strategist for Goldman Sachs before leaving for Silicon Valley, where he eventually started an ad-tech startup, AdGrok, which he later sold to Twitter. He worked as a product manager at Facebook between 2011 and 2013. In addition to his book, Garc√≠a Mart√≠nez has written for publications including Wired.
    

            On Monday, Business Insider noted Garc√≠a Mart√≠nez‚Äôs new position, citing his LinkedIn profile. By Tuesday evening, some Apple employees began circulating an internal ‚Äúletter of concern,‚Äù citing several of Garc√≠a Mart√≠nez‚Äôs passages in ‚ÄúChaos Monkeys‚Äù as problematic. The employees argued, in a letter viewed by CNN Business, that the passages are in direct opposition to Apple‚Äôs commitment to inclusion.
    

            To illustrate their point, the letter ‚Äî which was first reported on by tech news site The Verge on Wednesday after it accumulated more than 2,000 employees‚Äô signatures ‚Äî included excerpts from his writing.
    

            ‚ÄúMost women in the Bay Area are soft and weak, cosseted and naive despite their claims of worldliness, and generally full of s**t,‚Äù read a sentence in one passage from ‚ÄúChaos Monkeys.‚Äù It continued, ‚ÄúThey have their self-regarding entitlement feminism, and ceaselessly vaunt their independence, but the reality is, come the epidemic plague or foreign invasion, they‚Äôd become precisely the sort of useless baggage you‚Äôd trade for a box of shotgun shells or a jerry can of diesel.‚Äù
    

            Another book excerpt cited in the letter detailed startup funding, and included this sentence: ‚ÄúTo make an analogy, a capped note is like having to seduce five women one after the other, while an equity round is having to convince five women to do a sixsome with you.‚Äù
    

            ‚ÄúWe are profoundly distraught by what this hire means for Apple‚Äôs commitment to its inclusion goals, as well as its real and immediate impact on those working near Mr. Garc√≠a Mart√≠nez. It calls into question parts of our system of inclusion at Apple, including hiring panels, background checks, and our process to ensure our existing culture of inclusion is strong enough to withstand individuals who don‚Äôt share our inclusive values,‚Äù read the letter. 
    

            It also demanded the company investigate how Garc√≠a Mart√≠nez‚Äôs ‚Äúpublished views on women and people of color were missed or ignored‚Äù in the hiring process and come up with a ‚Äúclear plan of action to prevent this from happening again.‚Äù
    

            ‚ÄúGiven Mr. Garc√≠a Mart√≠nez‚Äôs history of publishing overtly racist and sexist remarks about his former colleagues, we are concerned that his presence at Apple will contribute to an unsafe working environment for our colleagues who are at risk of public harassment and private bullying,‚Äù the letter also said.
    

            Garc√≠a Mart√≠nez did not immediately respond to a request for comment from CNN Business, though he did appear to view a direct message sent to his verified Twitter profile.
    

            CNN Business (then known as CNN Money) reviewed ‚ÄúChaos Monkeys‚Äù in June 2016, saying at the time that it reads as if it‚Äôs four years worth of ‚ÄúMedium posts from a scorned man.‚Äù 
    

            While employees at tech companies like Google and Facebook have on occasion in recent years been publicly vocal about issues pertaining to internal culture, this episode has been a rare display of dissent among Apple‚Äôs workforce spilling into view. Numerous Apple employees took to Twitter on Wednesday to communicate openly about it, underscoring how important some felt it was for the company to address the situation.
    

            ‚ÄúThe reason I took to this letter as opposed to some other method is while I do trust in Apple‚Äôs culture and my leadership to do the right thing this was still starkly contradictory to that trust and those feelings,‚Äù Cher, an Apple engineer who asked that her last name be withheld for privacy reasons, told CNN Business. 
    

            By Wednesday night, Apple confirmed to CNN Business that Garc√≠a Mart√≠nez no longer works at Apple.
    

            ‚ÄúAt Apple, we have always strived to create an inclusive, welcoming workplace where everyone is respected and accepted. Behavior that demeans or discriminates against people for who they are has no place here,‚Äù an Apple spokesman said.

Apple unveils iOS 15 with new features for post-pandemic life
Content:
